label: 321. Madame Baptiste to Bp Patrick Lynch -- November 8, 1863
description: Madame Baptiste writes to Bishop Patrick Lynch with news from the Ursuline Convent and Academy.  She muses on the anniversary of her vows and begs the Bishop to tell her all about President Davis' visit to Charleston.  She writes about obtaining a new cow for the convent "having disposed of one that was no account." November 8, 1863. 4p.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: B04 Page 01 MB Lynch Columbia A.K.D.G Ursuline Convent & Academy Columbia S.C. Nov 8th 1863 [In Upper Right Hand Margin] I expect you tomorrow morning Monday morning Nov 9th My dearest Brother, This day, thirteen years ago you officiated at my religious profession. Do you remember in Bank Street & how you mistook Sister Charles who was shedding tears for me & consequently broke down in your sermon? Every year adds to my debt of gratitude for my vocation & to my esteem for it. If I were only worthy of it. Well, you must pray for me that I may be. What a grand time out you have had in Charleston. How superb. No wonder you could not come to Columbia when you had such [In Left Hand Margin in longhand] you. I'm afraid she has no religious vocation. I'm sorry--if not. Pray for us all especially for Sr Gertrude who is very proud of her picture & for your own sister Ellen. Sr Baptista [In Right Hand Margin in longhand] Madame Lynch [End Page 1] grand doings down there with president Davis! How did you like him? My experience is that great people always diminish in proportion as I approach to them--the lens of my imagination no doubt being a much greater magnifier than that of my reason. Did I ever tell you that I once wrote to Mr. Jeff Davis & he answered me very amiably & cordially? I did then. You must come & tell us all about your time out. Our school has about 120 scholars counting externs--among whom Miss Singleton, Miss Freymont, Miss Taylor, Miss Seibles & Beauregard nice, little Proctor. We expect as a boarder Miss Douglas of Va., daughter of Senator D-- who I am told is one of the cleverest men of our time. She wishes to become a Catholic. Let me tell you [End Page 2] something good. We have been trying to get a good cow, having disposed of one that was no account. Mr. Kenney who is very kind, attended to the matter for us. He & Sister Frances are great friends. We saw an advertisement of a splendid cow, warranted to give 20 qts [quarts] per dime & wrote immediately to Mr. W.M. Rivers of Winnesboro S.C. to purchase it of him. Many others wrote at the same time & equally anxious, but he wrote to John that he supposed he was a Brother of Bishop Lynch whom he had the pleasure of knowing well & therefore he gave him the preference. So we are indebted to you for the cow & we got her, but I think also we are indebted to the prayers of the Sisters, who were very earnest in them. Mr. Rivers warrants[End Page 3] the cow to give 20 quarts a day & says, with good feeling she will, he thinks give 30. She is $600 delivered in Winnesboro. We should pay $1000 here for one much inferior. Just think I have yielded to the entreaties of Mr. Lapten or rather Mr. Cory & allowed the photographist [sic]--Mr Durber, to come & take Sister Ursula's picture! At the same time he took Sister Etienne's for her Father as long ago requested & others. I read a long letter from Poor Mrs. Monroe which I will show you. I wish you would write to her. She wishes you to visit Anderson where there are a few Catholics. Enclosed was a letter from Abb [Abby] Pinckney, who sends love to you & us. She intends settling his affairs & consecrating herself to God & religion. Miss Jones talks of writing to you. [Rest of Letter cut off][End Page 4]
